In addition, all employees receive recurring training in environmental, safety and medical emergencies.  Also, Jewell will conduct periodic training events with Converse County Emergency Management Agencies.

DRIVING DIRECTIONS
From - Douglas Wyoming - WY-59 N 54.4. miles - Left turn then next right turn. From - Wright Wyoming - WY-59 S 18.6 miles - right turn then next right turn.

ly, the Jewell Gas Plant will conduct compliance audits every three years.  Jewell Gas Plant employs a third party to conduct the audit to ensure impartiality and a fresh perspective.  The audit results and any findings are shared with all personnel at a regularly scheduled safety event.  In addition, the final report is available at the Control Room for reference.

All audit findings are corrected in a timely fashion based upon priority ranking.  A record of all findings and the actions taken to resolve them is maintained at the hub for the two most recent audits.

CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Jewell Gas Plant has safety features to manage potential hazards, contain and control a spill, detect a release, mitigate the consequences of a release and ensure the continued safe operation of the process.  These features include:
 1.  Monitoring and control with SCADA software.
 2.  Management, surveillance and control by trained onsite operational personnel.
 3.  Offsite monitoring and shutdown capabilities.
 4.  Hazardous chemical and gas level detection, alarm and automatic shutdown.

Containment and control features include:
 1.  Pressure relief devices to avoid over pressurizing.
 2.  Valves that control and/or isolate part or all of the process.
 3.  Interlocks and shutdowns for specific process parameters.
 4.  Curbing and/or diking to contain spills.

Active and Passive mitigation features:
 1.  Fire extinguishing equipment.
 2.  Established and documented emergency procedures.
 3.  Coordination with emergency responders.
 4.  Personal Protective Equipment and other safety equipment.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Jewell Gas Plant has had no accidental releases in the past 5 years that have resulted in offsite consequences.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Jewell Gas Plant operates under the Denver Division Emergency Response Plan and the Jewell Supplement to that plan.  This supplement contains a site specific Emergency Action Plan including a drawing showin

intenance activities at the plant are performed safely.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE
The Jewell Gas Plant has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes. This system requires that changes such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including operating conditions of the process), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, equipment information, and operating procedures are updated prior to incorporating these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel and affected contractors are provided any necessary training on the change.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
The Jewell Gas Plant promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the factors that may have led to the incident, and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and reviews these results to Jewell management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the recommendations. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future and revalidated PHAs.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS
To determine that the Accident Prevention Program is functioning proper

to ensure that:
 1.  Appropriate training has been conducted.
 2.  Equipment, instruments, safety equipment and other elements are properly installed.
 3.  Valves and controls are in the normal/safe position.
 4.  Compressors and process equipment have been prepared for startup.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
The elements of the Jewell Gas Plant Mechanical Integrity program are periodic tests and inspections, regular maintenance, trained personnel, work order systems, written procedures and  record keeping.  The program includes pressure vessels, atmospheric tanks, piping, relief and vent systems, process equipment, pumps, compressors as well as dehydration, hot oil and flaring equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training including:
(1) an overview of the process, 
(2) safety and health hazards, 
(3) applicable maintenance procedures, 
(4) emergency procedures, and 
(5) work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Written inspection, testing and maintenance procedures provide that work is performed properly, and serve as a basis for training maintenance personnel in their assigned duties

Inspections and tests are performed to ensure that the equipment functions as intended and to establish a baseline for future monitoring. If a deficiency is identified that presents a safety concern, Jewell personnel will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service.

SAFE WORK PRACTICES
Safe work practices at the Jewell Gas Plant are defined by (1) the corporate safe practices manual, (2) a lockout/tag out procedure to isolate energy sources for equipment and piping undergoing maintenance, (3) a permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., hot work), and (4) a permit and procedure to verify that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. (5) procedures to control entry into the facility.  These practices along with training and procedures help to ensure that operating and ma

diagnose and repair the process equipment.  They must demonstrate a proficiency in their field of maintenance.  Only after the foreman of their discipline deems them competent, will they be allowed to perform maintenance tasks on process equipment.  Documentation of the individual's training and a record of their competence is kept as part of their personal training file.  Like the Operators, maintenance personnel receive ongoing training in their field and a formal refresher every three years.

CONTRACTORS
The Jewell Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce for construction, maintenance and testing.  To ensure that these contractors meet the safety and workplace standard, Jewell personnel complete contractor evaluation forms at regular intervals.  These completed forms are evaluated by safety and management to determine compliance with the established policies, procedures and guidelines.  Contractors must maintain an acceptable score on these reviews to continue working at the facility.  In addition, the Safety Group reviews the contractor's written safety program, its implementation, training and accident history to ensure that it complies with the Jewell Gas Plant requirements.

The Jewell Gas Plant provides contractors with:
 1.  A process overview
 2.  Safety orientation and ensures their understanding through testing.
 3.  Information about health and safety hazards.
 4.  Emergency evacuation procedures and mustering location.
 5.  All site specific safe work practices.

PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS
The Jewell Gas Plant will conduct Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR) before commencing initial process operations.  The records of those PSSRs will be maintained at the facility.  In addition a PSSR is conducted anytime a change is made that effects the Process Safety Information or before startup after a turnaround.  The records of those PSSRs are maintained as part of the MOC process.  Jewell uses a standardized corporate PSSR checklist. The PSSR serves

down and emergency shutdown.  In addition, the procedures list operating limits, consequence of deviations and responses, safety and health concerns and  safety systems.  Jewell uses these procedures for reference by experienced personnel and to provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.

Operating procedures are reviewed and modified whenever there are changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and/or facility.  Reviewing operating procedures is an element of the Management of Change (MoC) procedure.  In addition, the accuracy of all operating procedures are recertified annually.

TRAINING
Jewell Gas Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program to prepare potential process operators to safely and efficiently operate the facility.  Operators-in-training are taught an overview of the process, operating procedures, lock out/tag out, consequences of deviation, emergency response and operating parameters.  After an initial training phase, each candidate is paired with a senior operator for a minimum of 90 days to learn process specific tasks and duties.  The operator-in-training may remain paired with a senior operator beyond the 90 days if necessary, until they can demonstrate enough proficiency to satisfy the Operations Foreman.  The final step in becoming an operator is passing a rigorous written exam called the Compressor Operator Signoff (COS).  After all these requirements have been met, the new Operator can work independently.  New Operators are monitored by the Operations foremen.  Education is an ongoing process and as such, all operators receive periodic training related to their job duties.  In addition to all of this instruction, formal refresher training is conducted every three years. Each step of the operator training course is documented and becomes a permanent part of the employee's file.

Additionally, process maintenance personnel receive detailed training in each of the maintenance procedures as well as knowledge to

 8.  Electrical equipment class and ratings.
 9.  Maintenance history and records.
10.  Historical operating records.

The Jewell team then uses this information to assess potential hazards, modify maintenance steps and frequency, adjust operating procedures, change process and equipment functioning limits as well as alter safety requirements necessary to ensure the effectiveness of the accident prevention program.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS
The Jewell Gas Plant uses the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) findings to improve operating procedures, consequence of deviations and mechanical integrity.  The PHA systematically evaluates each process for potential hazards and then recommends change where needed.  These PHAs are revalidated every five years.

The PHA team is selected from management and employees.   Members are chosen based on their knowledge in operating and maintaining the process and engineering expertise.

The Jewell Gas Plant considers a variety of factors when conducting the PHA using a combination of the What if and HAZOP methods for evaluating potential hazards.  Some of the factors considered are:
 1.  Process Safety Information (PSI).
 2.  Cause and Effects.
 3.  Human factors.
 4.  Public health.
 5.  Environmental factors.
 6.  Safeguards in place.
 7.  Facility siting.
 8.  Incidents, accidents and near miss reports.
 9.  Management of Change (MoC) information.
10.  All previous PHAs.

The results of the PHAs are published and made available to all personnel.  The PHA follow-up items are promptly addressed based on their priority ranking.  The responses to the PHA recommendations are tracked until they are resolved. Jewell Gas Plant retains these records of previous PHAs. 

OPERATING PROCEDURES
The Jewell Gas Plant maintains easily obtainable operating procedures that address various aspects of the process.  These procedures cover normal startup, startup after turnaround, normal operation, temporary operation, emergency operation, normal shut

agement Plan (RMP) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standards.  Since the scope of these two programs encompass much of the same material, we have presented the pertinent information following the outline established in the PSM program.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
Employee participation is mandated by the corporate PSM manual.  In response to this mandate the Jewell Gas Plant has:
 1.  Created a matrix of required employee participation.
 2.  Posted information for employee participation in the Control Room.
 3.  Reported the finding for PHAs, Compliance Audits and incident investigations during regularly scheduled Safety Meetings.
 4.  Directly involved employees in the establishment of maintenance and operating procedures.
 5.  Sought input for training, both in subject matter and timing from employees.
 6.  Trained all employees in the Management of Change (MOC) process.
 7.  Included employee input in the Process Safety Information (PSI).
 8.  Included employees with appropriate knowledge in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).
 9.  Made all information associated with Accident Prevention available to all employees at the facility.

The Jewell Gas Plant actively encourages employee participation in all aspects of operation and safety.  The result is a more invested group of personnel and an ever increasing accident prevention awareness.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION 
The Jewell Gas Plant maintains a variety of information used to analyze the steps necessary to ensure the safe operation of the process.  This information includes:
 1.  Inventories of regulated chemicals.
 2.  Data on chemical properties and associated release and exposure hazards and appropriate responses.
 3.  Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams.
 4.  Relief and vent system studies and designs.
 5.  Process design as well as operating parameters and limits.
 6.  Safety interlocks.
 7.  Information on equipment design, materials, ratings and te

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
EOG Resources has a longstanding commitment to public welfare and worker safety.  EOG addresses accidental release prevention through four factors:  design, training, operating parameters and regular maintenance.  Through design efforts, we have limited the public exposure.  Through training, we have prepared our personnel to respond effectively.  Limiting the operating parameters reduces the stress on process equipment.  And regular maintenance serves to prolong equipment life as well as discover potential problems before they become a safety issue.

Should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur, EOG personnel will evaluate the  conditions, take actions within their capabilities to minimize the risk and notify the appropriate outside agencies.

FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
Jewell Gas Plant is located in a rural area in Converse County, Wyoming.  The Jewell Gas Plant separates field gas; producing a residue gas product, HD5 propane product, NGL product, and stabilized RVP 12 condensate. The plant capacity is 50 MMscfd. The residue gas connects to the MIGC pipeline. The HD5, NGL, and stabilized condensate is transported via automated truck loadout. The plant includes a Two-Tower Stabilizer, Refrigerated Joule-Thompson Unit, and Fractionation Unit.
Additional facilities constituting the Jewell Gas Plant include:
	Field condensate receipt and processing to NGL and stabilized condensate (12RVP);
	Pressurized and atmospheric product storage;
	HD5 propane odorant injection.
